adjectives.description: total (comparative more total, superlative most total)

entries.meaning: Entire; relating to the whole of something.
examples: The total book is rubbish from start to finish.â€ƒ The total number of votes cast is 3,270.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) (of a function) Defined on all possible inputs.
examples: The Ackermann function is one of the simplest and earliest examples of a total computable function that is not primitive recursive.

entries.meaning: An amount obtained by the addition of smaller amounts.
examples: A total of Â£145 was raised by the bring-and-buy stall.

verbs.description: total (third-person singular simple present totals, present participle (UK) totalling or (US) totaling, simple past and past participle (UK) totalled or (US) totaled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To add up; to calculate the sum of.
examples: When we totalled the takings, we always got a different figure.

entries.meaning: To equal a total of; to amount to.
examples: That totals seven times so far.

entries.meaning: (transitive, US, slang) To demolish; to wreck completely. (from total loss)
examples: Honey, Iâ€™m OK, but Iâ€™ve totaled the car.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To amount to; to add up to.
